definitions: control and arrange clients for prostitutes while taking part of their earnings
decorate or customize something in an ostentatious or flashy manner
examples: He was arrested for attempting to pimp vulnerable women
The documentary exposed how gangs pimp young girls in cities
They decided to pimp their old car with chrome wheels
The TV show specializes in pimping ordinary homes into mansions

definitions: fasten or secure something using a pin or similar pointed fastener
hold someone or something firmly in position preventing movement or escape
attribute blame or responsibility for something to a particular person
examples: She carefully pinned the corsage to her dress
The tailor pinned the hem before sewing it permanently
The wrestler pinned his opponent to the mat
Fallen debris pinned the driver inside the wrecked car
They tried to pin the theft on an innocent employee
Investigators finally pinned the crime on the right suspect

definitions: grip something tightly between finger and thumb causing sharp pressure or pain
steal something especially in a sneaky or petty manner
cause financial difficulty or hardship through economic pressure or constraint
examples: She pinched his arm to wake him up quickly
The tight shoes pinched her toes throughout the wedding
Someone pinched my wallet while I was distracted
The kids were caught pinching candy from the store
Rising costs are pinching middle-class families across the country
The budget cuts will pinch social services most severely

definitions: suffer with intense longing or yearning for someone or something absent
gradually waste away through grief, longing, or illness becoming weak
examples: She pined for her homeland after years of exile
The dog pined for its owner during the long separation
The prisoner pined away in solitary confinement for months
He pined away after his wife's death from grief

definitions: make or cause to make a short high-pitched ringing sound
send a signal to check connectivity or location of a network device
contact someone briefly typically through electronic messaging for quick communication
examples: The metal ball pinged against the concrete wall repeatedly
Bullets pinged off the armored vehicle during the firefight
The IT department pinged the server to check its status
Your phone constantly pings cell towers to maintain connection
I'll ping you tomorrow about the meeting details
She pinged her team on Slack for a quick update

definitions: restrain or immobilize someone by binding their arms tightly to their body
cut the flight feathers of a bird to prevent it from flying
examples: The guards pinioned the prisoner's arms before transporting him
She was pinioned against the wall unable to move freely
The zookeepers pinioned the flamingos to keep them from escaping
Farmers sometimes pinion domestic geese to prevent them flying away

definitions: become or cause to become pink in color through blushing or exposure
cut a zigzag or scalloped edge on fabric using special scissors
examples: Her cheeks pinked with embarrassment at the compliment
The sunset pinked the clouds above the mountains beautifully
She carefully pinked the edges of the fabric with scissors
The seamstress pinked all the seams to prevent fraying

definitions: reach or cause to reach the highest point of achievement or development
examples: Her career pinnacled when she became the company's youngest CEO
The empire pinnacled during the reign of its greatest emperor

definitions: find or locate something with exact precision and accuracy
identify or determine something with complete accuracy and specificity
examples: Scientists pinpointed the earthquake's epicenter within minutes of occurrence
GPS technology can pinpoint your location to within three meters
Doctors struggled to pinpoint the cause of her symptoms
The investigation pinpointed the exact moment the security breach occurred

definitions: develop or be the first to use or apply new methods or techniques
be among the first to explore or settle a new territory or area
examples: Marie Curie pioneered research in radioactivity and nuclear physics
The company pioneered the use of artificial intelligence in healthcare
Early settlers pioneered the western territories despite numerous hardships
Astronauts will pioneer human settlements on Mars within decades

definitions: defeat someone by a very small margin especially at the last moment
make a short high-pitched sound like a young bird or electronic device
examples: She pipped her rival at the finish line by milliseconds
The underdog team pipped the champions in the final seconds
The chicks pipped constantly calling for their mother's attention
The smoke detector pipped every thirty seconds needing new batteries

definitions: transport or convey liquid, gas, or information through pipes or channels
play music on a pipe or similar wind instrument
say or sing something in a high-pitched or shrill voice
examples: The company pipes natural gas to millions of homes nationwide
They piped water from the mountain spring to the village
The bagpiper piped traditional Scottish melodies at the wedding
Sailors were piped aboard with ceremonial music from the boatswain
The child piped up with an unexpected question during class
She piped a greeting from across the crowded room

definitions: stimulate or arouse interest, curiosity, or excitement about something
hurt someone's pride or self-respect causing irritation or resentment
examples: The mysterious advertisement piqued everyone's curiosity about the product
Her unusual accent piqued his interest in her background
His dismissive comments piqued her professional pride considerably
She was piqued by his failure to acknowledge her contribution

definitions: illegally copy or use copyrighted material without permission or payment
attack and rob ships at sea as a pirate
examples: Millions of people pirate movies and music from the internet
The company's software was pirated and sold in foreign markets
Criminals continue to pirate cargo ships off the African coast
Armed groups pirated several oil tankers in international waters

definitions: set someone or something in conflict or competition against another
remove the hard stone or seed from the center of fruit
mark or become marked with small hollows or indentations on surface
examples: The tournament will pit the champions against each other
The debate pitted traditional values against modern progressive ideas
She carefully pitted the cherries before making the pie
The recipe requires you to pit and slice the peaches
Years of acne had pitted his face with small scars
Acid rain has pitted the marble statues over time

definitions: throw or toss something with force toward a target or destination
erect or set up a tent or temporary camp structure
present or propose an idea, product, or service persuasively to others
set or move at a particular angle or slope especially downward
examples: He pitched the ball with incredible speed to the batter
She pitched her empty can into the recycling bin
They pitched their tent near the lake before sunset
The scouts pitched camp in a clearing surrounded by trees
She pitched her business idea to several potential investors yesterday
The advertising agency pitched three different campaigns to the client
The ship pitched violently in the storm's massive waves
The roof was pitched at a steep angle for snow

definitions: lift, move, or throw hay or other material using a pitchfork tool
force or thrust someone into a position or situation suddenly
examples: The farmhands pitchforked hay into the barn's upper loft
He pitchforked the compost onto the garden beds carefully
She was suddenly pitchforked into a leadership role unexpectedly
The scandal pitchforked him into the media spotlight overnight

definitions: remove the soft white tissue from the center of plant stems or citrus
examples: The chef carefully pithed the oranges before using the zest
You should pith the elder stems before making the flute

definitions: feel sorrow, sympathy, or compassion for someone's misfortune or suffering
examples: She pitied the homeless man shivering in the cold rain
I pity anyone who has to work in such conditions

definitions: turn or rotate on a single point or axis like a hinge
depend crucially on or have as the central determining factor
examples: The dancer pivoted gracefully on one foot during the performance
The door pivots on well-oiled hinges opening smoothly
The company's success pivots on this new product launch entirely
The entire case pivots on the testimony of one witness

definitions: publicly display or advertise something using placards or posted notices
examples: Protesters placarded the building with signs demanding justice immediately
The walls were placarded with advertisements for the upcoming concert

definitions: make someone less angry or hostile by doing something to please them
examples: She tried to placate the angry customer with a full refund
The government attempted to placate protesters with minor policy changes

definitions: put something in a particular position or location carefully
arrange for someone to be in a particular situation or context
identify or remember where you encountered someone or something before
achieve a particular position or ranking in a competition
examples: She placed the vase carefully on the antique table
Place your hands on your hips for this exercise
The agency placed him in a senior management position
They placed their daughter in an excellent private school
I can't quite place where I've seen her before
She finally placed the accent as being from Scotland
Our team placed third in the national championship tournament
The horse placed second in its first race ever

definitions: cause continual trouble, distress, or annoyance to someone or something
infest or affect with disease or something harmful in large numbers
examples: Financial problems have plagued the company for several years
Doubts plagued her mind throughout the difficult decision process
Locusts plagued the crops destroying the entire harvest season
Rats plagued the old warehouse making it unsafe for workers

definitions: speak or express something in a direct and clear manner without ambiguity
examples: Let me plain with you about the situation here
She plained her feelings without any hesitation or doubt

definitions: decide on and arrange the details of something in advance methodically
have the intention or purpose to do something in the future
examples: They carefully planned every detail of their wedding ceremony
The committee planned the conference agenda months in advance
We plan to visit Europe next summer for vacation
She plans on studying medicine after finishing her degree

definitions: smooth a wooden surface by cutting thin shavings with a tool
glide or soar through air or water with little effort
examples: The carpenter carefully planed the rough boards until perfectly smooth
He planed the door edge so it would close properly
The eagle planed effortlessly on the warm air currents
The boat planed across the calm water at high speed

definitions: cover or provide something with wooden planks as flooring or siding
cook food especially fish on a wooden plank for flavor
examples: They planked the old bridge with new sturdy boards
The builders planked the deck with pressure-treated lumber
The chef planked the salmon on cedar for added flavor
Native Americans traditionally planked fish over open fires

definitions: put a seed, plant, or tree in soil to grow
establish or place something firmly in a particular position or context
secretly place something for discovery by others often for deception
examples: She planted tomatoes in her backyard garden this spring
Farmers plant corn in rows for easier harvesting
He planted his feet firmly before lifting the weight
They planted a new factory in the industrial district
Someone planted drugs in his car to frame him
The spy planted listening devices throughout the embassy

definitions: cover walls or surfaces with plaster material for smoothing or decoration
cover a surface with things stuck or spread all over it
defeat someone overwhelmingly in a game or competition
examples: The workers plastered the walls before painting them white
They plastered over the cracks in the ceiling
She plastered posters all over her bedroom walls
His face was plastered with mud after the game
Our team plastered them with a score of fifty to ten
The champion plastered his opponent in three straight rounds

definitions: braid or interweave strands of hair or material into a pattern
examples: She platted her daughter's hair into neat cornrows yesterday
The artisan platted strips of leather into a decorative belt

definitions: cover something with a thin layer of metal especially for protection
arrange and present food on a plate for serving
examples: The jeweler plated the silver ring with rhodium finish
They plated the steel parts with chrome for durability
The chef carefully plated each dish before sending it out
She plated the dessert with artistic chocolate drizzle decoration

definitions: engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than serious purpose
perform music on an instrument or reproduce recorded sound
perform a role in a dramatic production or behave deceptively
take part in a sport or contest as a competitor
be in operation or cause a machine or device to function
examples: The children played happily in the park all afternoon
Let's play a board game after dinner tonight
She plays violin in the city symphony orchestra beautifully
Can you play that song again on the stereo?
He played Hamlet in the school's Shakespeare production brilliantly
She's just playing dumb to avoid taking responsibility
Our team plays against the champions next Saturday afternoon
She plays tennis professionally earning millions in prize money
The fountain plays only during summer months for tourists
This DVD player won't play the disc properly anymore

definitions: make an emotional and earnest appeal or request to someone
present and argue a case before a court as legal representative
offer something as an excuse or justification for behavior
examples: She pleaded with him not to leave her alone
The prisoner pleaded for mercy from the judge
The lawyer pleaded his client's case brilliantly in court
She pleaded guilty to avoid a lengthy trial
He pleaded ignorance when questioned about the missing funds
Don't plead poverty when everyone knows you're wealthy

definitions: make a solemn promise or commitment to do something specific
give something as security for a loan or obligation
drink a toast to someone's health or success formally
examples: She pledged to donate half her salary to charity
The president pledged support for education reform initiatives
He pledged his house as collateral for the business loan
Students pledged their textbooks at the pawn shop
They pledged the queen's health at the state dinner
We pledge our friendship with this ceremonial drink

definitions: pledge or promise solemnly especially in marriage or engagement
examples: They plighted their troth in a traditional ceremony yesterday
The knight plighted his loyalty to the king forever

definitions: secretly make plans to carry out an illegal or harmful action
mark or indicate the position of something on a chart or map
devise the main story or sequence of events in a narrative
examples: They plotted to overthrow the government through military coup
The conspirators plotted against the king for many months
The navigator plotted their course across the Pacific Ocean
Scientists plotted the data points on a graph
The author carefully plotted her mystery novel's complex twists
They plotted the screenplay scene by scene together

definitions: turn over soil with a plough to prepare for planting crops
move forward forcefully through something that resists progress
invest large amounts of money or resources into something
examples: Farmers plough their fields every spring before planting season
They ploughed the land using traditional ox-drawn equipment
The ship ploughed through the stormy seas all night
She ploughed through the dense legal documents determinedly
They ploughed millions into developing the new technology
He ploughed his inheritance back into the family business

definitions: turn over soil with a plow to prepare for planting crops
move forward forcefully through something that resists progress
invest large amounts of money or resources into something
examples: The farmer plowed ten acres before the rain started
They plowed the field with a modern tractor attachment
The truck plowed through the deep snow effortlessly
He plowed through his homework despite feeling tired
The company plowed billions into research and development projects
She plowed her savings into starting a new business

definitions: pull out or remove something with a quick sharp movement
sound the strings of a musical instrument by pulling and releasing
show courage and determination in difficult or dangerous situations
examples: She plucked a rose from the garden for her mother
The chef plucked the chicken feathers before cooking it
He plucked the guitar strings creating a melodious tune
She plucked the harp beautifully during the concert performance
The firefighter plucked up courage to enter the burning building
She plucked up the nerve to ask for a raise

definitions: block or fill a hole or gap with something solid
promote or publicize something persistently especially a product or event
connect an electrical device to a power source using a plug
examples: The plumber plugged the leak with special waterproof sealant
They plugged the hole in the dam before flooding occurred
The actor plugged his new movie on every talk show
She constantly plugs her business on social media platforms
Plug the laptop in before the battery dies completely
He plugged the amplifier into the main sound system

definitions: measure the depth of water using a weighted line
examine or investigate something thoroughly to understand it completely
install or repair water pipes and plumbing fixtures in buildings
examples: Sailors plumbed the harbor depth before docking the ship
They plumbed the lake to find the deepest point
Researchers plumbed the depths of human psychology for answers
The detective plumbed every lead in the mysterious case
They plumbed the new bathroom with modern copper pipes
He plumbed the entire house during the renovation project

definitions: spread out in a shape resembling a feather or plume
pride or congratulate oneself on an achievement or quality
examples: Smoke plumed from the factory chimney into the sky
The volcano plumed ash high into the atmosphere
She plumed herself on her excellent negotiation skills
He plumed himself on closing the difficult deal

definitions: fall or drop straight down at high speed through the air
decrease rapidly in value or amount over a short time
examples: The damaged plane plummeted toward the ground terrifyingly fast
The BASE jumper plummeted for several seconds before opening parachute
Stock prices plummeted after the company announced bankruptcy proceedings
Temperatures plummeted to below freezing overnight causing widespread frost

definitions: make or become fuller, rounder, or fatter in appearance
drop, fall, or sit down heavily and suddenly
choose or opt for something decisively after consideration
examples: She plumped the cushions before the guests arrived
The rain plumped the dried grapes into juicy raisins
He plumped down on the sofa after work exhausted
She plumped her bag on the table with relief
After much debate, they plumped for the seaside vacation
She finally plumped for the red dress over blue

definitions: steal goods from a place or person using force especially during war
use or take resources carelessly and wastefully depleting them
examples: Vikings plundered coastal villages throughout medieval Europe
The army plundered the conquered city taking everything valuable
Companies plundered the forest's natural resources for decades
They plundered the earth's minerals without considering sustainability

definitions: jump or dive quickly and energetically into water or downward
fall suddenly and uncontrollably in amount, value, or level
push or thrust something quickly and forcefully into something
examples: She plunged into the pool to escape the heat
The waterfall plunges two hundred feet into the canyon
Oil prices plunged to their lowest level in years
The company's reputation plunged after the scandal broke
He plunged the knife into the watermelon to cut it
She plunged her hands into the soapy dishwater

definitions: work steadily at one's trade or business especially involving tools
travel regularly over a route especially for commercial purposes
supply someone persistently with food, drink, or questions
examples: The craftsman plied his trade for over forty years
Fishermen plied their nets in the early morning hours
Ferries ply between the island and mainland every hour
Taxis plied the streets looking for late-night customers
They plied him with drinks trying to loosen his tongue
Reporters plied her with questions about the scandal

definitions: put something into one's pocket or a small space
take money dishonestly especially by embezzling or stealing
suppress or hide one's feelings, pride, or principles
examples: He pocketed his keys and headed for the door
She pocketed the receipt for her expense report
The manager pocketed thousands from the company's cash register
He pocketed the donations meant for the charity
She pocketed her pride and apologized for the mistake
He had to pocket his anger during the meeting

definitions: produce seed pods as part of plant growth and reproduction
remove peas or beans from their pods before cooking
examples: The pea plants are podding well this growing season
These beans pod heavily producing abundant harvest each year
She podded fresh peas for the evening dinner preparation
They spent hours podding beans from the garden harvest
